docs.lead_paragraph: The agency’s decision to prohibit the industrial chemical bisphenol A in baby bottles and children’s drinking cups came upon the request of the chemical industry.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Bans BPA From Baby Bottles and Sippy Cups
headline.main: F.D.A. Makes It Official: BPA Can’t Be Used in Baby Bottles and Cups
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Makes It Official: Chemical Can’t Be Used In Baby Bottles and Cups

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration says baby bottles and children's drinking cups can no longer contain the industrial chemical bisphenol A; manufacturers have already stopped using it in baby bottles and sippy cups; FDA says its decision is response to a request from the chemical industry; substance can still be used in other containers, including for formula.
docs.snippet: The agency’s decision to prohibit the industrial chemical bisphenol A in baby bottles and children’s drinking cups came upon the request of the chemical industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: The slogans and scare stories have taken over the discussion. The Affordable Care Act is humane, fiscally viable and Democrats should be out there defending it.
docs.abstract: Bill Keller Op-Ed column contends that the Affordable Care Act is a humane and fiscally viable program, and that slogans and scare tactics have hijacked the national debate about its merits; argues that Democrats should become more confrontational in defending the law, and should no longer allow Republicans to frame it in the public eye.
docs.snippet: The slogans and scare stories have taken over the discussion. The Affordable Care Act is humane, fiscally viable and Democrats should be out there defending it.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
